relevant_cases: 19087:Original case - Shows classic bear paw sign, staghorn calculus, renal enlargement, perinephric inflammation, and non-functioning kidney - demonstrates complete diagnostic picture of diffuse XGP;18308:Clear bear paw sign with staghorn calculus and perinephric fat stranding - shows key diagnostic imaging features including dilated calyces surrounded by thin parenchymal rim;19103:Demonstrates bear paw sign in bifid ureter with staghorn calculus - shows diagnostic features in anatomical variant and perirenal inflammatory extension;17200:Classic presentation with staghorn calculus on radiograph, renal enlargement, cortical thinning, and perinephric inflammatory changes - shows typical clinical and imaging triad;14129:Shows staghorn calculus with water-attenuation cavities and peripelvic fat stranding - demonstrates chronic destructive process with fatty xanthomatous deposits;17028:Clear bear paw sign with air-fluid levels in dilated calyces, perinephric fat stranding, and no contrast excretion - shows advanced diffuse form with extrarenal extension;2523:Advanced diffuse form with contracted kidney, staghorn calculus, and extensive perinephric lipomatous expansion - demonstrates late-stage XGP with replacement lipomatosis;2802:Bilateral XGP case showing renal enlargement with lobulated masses replacing parenchyma - demonstrates rare bilateral presentation and MR imaging characteristics;19037:Shows bear paw sign with fat-density areas (xanthomas), perirenal fat stranding, and staging according to Malek classification - demonstrates comprehensive CT features;9344:Bilateral staghorn calculi with extensive perinephric fatty tissue and psoas muscle extension - shows advanced chronic XGP with extrarenal complications

19172:Primary case showing classic features: thin central septum dividing uterus into two hemicavities, placental implantation on septum, fetus extending across septum - demonstrates all key diagnostic features for Gravid septate uterus with septal placental implantation;11882:Shows septate uterus with placenta previa - demonstrates association between uterine septum and abnormal placental implantation, helps understand risk factors and complications;5700:Bicornuate pregnancy case - important for differential diagnosis, shows how to distinguish bicornuate from septate uterus based on fundal cleft and external contour;10893:Uterus didelphys case - demonstrates complete separation of uterine horns, helps differentiate septate uterus (internal septum) from didelphys (complete duplication);16525:Bicornuate uterus with pregnancy - shows two distinct cornua, helps distinguish external fundal cleft of bicornuate vs internal septum of septate uterus;9850:Herlyn-Werner-Wunderlich syndrome - demonstrates complex Mullerian anomalies with renal associations, helps understand spectrum of uterine malformations;18774:Unicornuate uterus case - shows single uterine horn, important for differential diagnosis against septate uterus which has two hemicavities;9066:Juvenile cystic adenomyosis - demonstrates differential diagnosis for uterine masses that could be confused with septate uterus features;18328:Interstitial ectopic pregnancy - mentions cornual pregnancy in septate/bicornuate uterus, shows importance of identifying uterine anomalies in ectopic pregnancies;12660:Uterine rupture post-septoplasty - demonstrates complications of uterine septum surgery, shows importance of monitoring septate uterus pregnancies

1828:Sagittal and axial post-contrast MR show a lobulated, heterogeneously enhancing pineal mass with subsequent multiple nodular leptomeningeal and ependymal enhancing deposits ("sugar-icing" pattern) — demonstrates typical CSF dissemination of pineoblastoma.;6806:Sagittal T1 and post-contrast images show an irregular, heterogeneously enhancing pineal mass that invades the tectum and extends through the aqueduct causing obstructive hydrocephalus — illustrates aggressive, infiltrative behavior of pineoblastoma.;16434:Non-contrast CT and post-contrast MR show a mildly hyperdense pineal mass with central calcification and avid, homogeneous enhancement — characteristic of germinoma and useful to distinguish from pineoblastoma which is usually heterogeneous and often lacks central calcification.;15105:Serial MR images show a cystic pineal lesion with nodular/thickened enhancing wall and interval growth — a pattern that can mimic pineoblastoma (cystic/necrotic malignant lesion) and emphasizes the imaging features that raise suspicion for pineoblastoma vs benign pineal cyst.;5483:CT and MR show a multiloculated heterogeneous pineal mass with areas of fat signal/low attenuation and calcification with fat droplets in subarachnoid spaces — classic for teratoma and helps exclude pineoblastoma which lacks macroscopic fat and typically shows homogeneous/heterogeneous solid enhancement and CSF dissemination.

12226:Pelvic fluid collection is partially opacified on delayed/excretory-phase CT (higher attenuation within collection) with a visible track of contrast from the right distal ureter into the collection — classic CT-urography demonstration of iatrogenic ureteral leak/urinoma after pelvic surgery.;9710:Perinephric/retroperitoneal fluid collection shows marked increased attenuation on excretory-phase CT consistent with extravasated opacified urine; 3D reformations show relationship to collecting system — demonstrates how delayed imaging identifies urinoma and differentiates it from abscess/seroma.;12181:Medial perirenal extraluminal opacified urine originating at the ureteropelvic junction on excretory-phase CT with opacified proximal ureter — example of ureter/UPJ disruption causing urinoma and how delayed phase localizes injury level.;9613:CT urography shows clear extravasation of iodinated contrast from both ureters into a large retroperitoneal fluid collection (urinoma) with progressive increase in attenuation on delayed images — demonstrates direct visualization of contrast leak and extent of urinoma.;12239:Delayed excretory-phase CT shows opacification of the vagina (and tract) from the urinary bladder/ureteral system indicating a urinary fistula; useful to distinguish vesicovaginal or uretero-vaginal fistula versus urinoma and to localize source of urinary leak after pelvic surgery.

8890:MRI shows a well-defined tenosynovial mass isointense to muscle on T1 with no susceptibility artifacts on GRE (absence of hemosiderin) and collagenous hypocellular histology — imaging pattern supports fibroma of the tendon sheath (FTS);1066:GCTTS case with low-intermediate signal on T1 and T2 attributed to hemosiderin and strong post-contrast enhancement — demonstrates imaging features (hemosiderin-related low signal and marked enhancement) that help differentiate GCTTS from FTS;18540:Localized tenosynovial giant cell tumour showing T1 hypointense mass, areas of signal drop on susceptibility/FFE (blooming from hemosiderin) and prominent enhancement — useful to exclude FTS when susceptibility artifacts are present;15087:Diffuse tenosynovial giant cell tumour (PVNS) with T1/T2 low-signal hemosiderin, bone erosions and enhancing synovium on MRI — these features (blooming, erosions) contrast with FTS and aid differential diagnosis;885:GCTTS example with low signal intensity on T1 and T2 due to hemosiderin deposition evident on MR images — reinforces that presence of hemosiderin/susceptibility favors GCTTS over FTS

12978:CT shows a large thin-walled multiloculated mesenteric cystic mass with thin enhancing septa and fluid attenuation (8-10 HU) matching the multiloculated appearance of lymphangioma.;6424:CT demonstrates a large lobulated thin-walled multicystic mesenteric mass with contents varying from water to fat attenuation and intimate bowel relation — imaging evidence of chylous/fatty content and multiloculation typical of lymphangioma.;19174:CT shows a multiloculated cystic mesenteric lesion with thin enhancing internal septa, lobulated borders, mass effect and complications (small-bowel obstruction, whirlpool sign) — illustrates how lymphangioma can present with inflammatory/complication-related changes and enhancing septa as in the target case.;8152:CT and MRI demonstrate a cystic mesenteric lesion with central fat density/signal and circular wall enhancement plus surrounding mesenteric inflammatory changes — directly supports chylous (fat) content and infection/inflammation in lymphangioma.;17202:Ultrasound and CT show an enteric duplication cyst with thick enhancing wall, ‘gut-signature’ (inner echogenic mucosa and outer muscular layer) and a shared wall with the duodenum — useful to distinguish duplication cyst from lymphangioma which lacks the gut wall signature.;5016:CT shows a cystic omental teratoma with fat-fluid level and calcified/solid Rokitansky protuberance — demonstrates imaging features (calcification/solid elements) that favour teratoma over lymphangioma and help exclude this differential.
